titleStmt.title: Variants of IPFV of I-w verbs (3sg.m in a pattern)
titleStmt.author: Veronika Engler

sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for IPFV of I-w verbs (3sg.m in a pattern)- ex. yūCvC and then give example.

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Most verbs have short and a long form that have the same meaning: yūǧaʕ and yəǧaʕ. Only the verb yəsaʕ (to grasp) and yūsaʕ (to become broader) differs in its meaning.
only short forms like in Palmyra (yakaʕ, yaṛam, yabas, yaṛaṯ)
The /ú/ in the example is a stressed short vowel
yōCvC is the most common pattern, yet, yawCvC may also occur, e.g. 'he arrives' can be both yōṣal and yawṣal.
yōCvC is the most common pattern, yet, yawCvC may also occur, e.g. 'he arrives' can be both yōṣal and yawṣal.
yōCvC is the most common pattern, yet, yawCvC may also occur, e.g. 'he arrives' can be both yōṣal and yawṣal.
yōCvC is the most common pattern, yet, yawCvC may also occur, e.g. 'he arrives' can be both yōṣal and yawṣal.
long vowels have not been preserved in this dialect, i.e. no contrast u : ū
